Apparently u kids don't understand how "net-worth" is calculated.lol I spy some children who flunked out of their economics courses. A person's net-worth is not solely dependent upon the amount of physical currency that they hold. That assertion is beyond retarded. It's based on ASSETS. Like real estate holdings, valuable physical assets, mineral holdings, fiat exchanges and economic influence over entire nations' GDP, which the Rothschilds, DeMedici's, DuPonts, etc. have all proven to have. The bulk of which has been calculated for the Rothschild Family by multiple sources, including Forbes and the WSJ, at being(possibly) well over $300+ trillion. Then there are reports from historians who've calculated the flow of goods and services between that family and both sides of every major war since the Napoleonic wars, and have calculated their gross-earnings to have been around $500 trillion. And if you really think that's more money than exists in the entire world, you're a special kind of retarded.lol the US alone has enough physical assets to be worth far more than $500 trillion. Which is why we can dump $1 trillion on government programs that make us zero money at the drop of a hat, and still have money to spare despite our being "broke". My own family was very wealthy for nearly ten centuries in Northern Italy (my father's side). They owned a huge amount of land and over 20 castles and palaces through that time. They also sponsored a lot of artworks and had large collections, some of which hang in the National Gallery in London today. By the early 20th century they had none of this left. 
At university I was was quite interested in finding out how this could happen. Basically it comes down to the Industrial Revolution and the rise of the so called bourgeois as the most financially powerful class. A reordering of society. My family operated in a feudal mode. Land rented to peasants etc. They were also paid to provide troops for Venice and defend the border with Milan. Sources of income that either ceased to exist or be profitable. 
The world changed, but they did not. They could not compete with the industrialists and fell by the wayside. The industrialists became the elite class and shaped society to their advantage. Not many old aristocratic families in Europe adjusted well from feudalism to capitalism. 
I sometimes wonder what comes next. We began as nomadic and hunter gatherer societies etc, then we had slave based systems like Rome and in Ancient Greece. Then came feudalism followed by capitalism. Is that it, or is there more to come? Capitalism is based on competition, growth, and consumption etc. Due to finite resources and environmental impacts, I can not see it being sustainable long term. I think we will be forced to adapt to an evolved system beyond what we do now.

There are many things in your speech that I cannot check. 
One of your comments however reflects a profound disregard for German history : the title of "Emperor" of the Holy Empire carried little more than a lot of prestige, and its holders hardly ruled anything but their own lands, and the holder of a German fiefdom was its actual ruler, not its "governor". 

This allowed the ruler of some of the richest lands to become quite rich, as could in no way be expropriated by the Emperor. The money flow rather went the other way round : at the death of the emperor not only his sons did not inherit anything, but it was up to seven German noblemen called "Electors", three of them bishops, to designate the new emperor. The trophy usually went to the highest bidder ... 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prince-elector
